description: Numbers n such that (3^n - 1)/2 is prime.
comments: If n is in the sequence and m=3^(n-1) then m is a term of A033632 (phi(sigma(m)) = sigma(phi(m)), so 3^(A028491-1) is a subsequence of A033632. For example since 9551 is in the sequence, phi(sigma(3^9550)) = sigma(phi(3^9550)). - _Farideh Firoozbakht_, Feb 09 2005Salas lists these, except 3, in "Open Problems" p.6 [March 2012], and proves that the Cantor primes > 3 are exactly the prime-valued cyclotomic polynomials of the form Phi_s(3^{s^j}) == 1 (mod 4).Also, n such that 3^n-1 is a semiprime - see also A080892. - _M. F. Hasler_, Mar 19 2013
